metadata.case_name: Harishankar Bagla & Smt. Gomti Bagla v. State of Madhya Pradesh

facts.text: Appellant Harishankar Bagla and his wife Smt. Gomti Bagla arrested at Itarsi by Railway Police on 29th November 1948 for contravention of section 7 of Essential Supplies (Temporary Powers) Act 1946 read with clause 3 of Cotton Textiles (Control of Movement) Order 1948
Found in possession of new cotton cloth weighing over six maunds being taken from Bombay to Kanpur without permit
Case initiated as Criminal Case No. 75 of 1949 before Magistrate 1st Class Hoshangabad
High Court withdrew case to itself on 3rd September 1951 as it involved constitutional issues

High Court by order dated 15th September 1952 upheld sections 3 and 4 of Act and Control Order as constitutional; held section 6 unconstitutional but not affecting prosecution; directed records sent back to trial court
Leave to appeal granted to appellants and respondent with certificates under Articles 132 and 134
Appellants never applied for a permit

legal_issues.text: Whether sections 3 and 4 of Essential Supplies (Temporary Powers) Act 1946 and Cotton Textiles Control Order contravene Article 19(1)(f) and (g)
Whether section 3 involves excessive delegation of legislative power
Whether section 6 is ultra vires and affects section 3
Whether Control Order contravenes sections 27, 28 and 41 of Indian Railways Act
Whether section 6 of the Act is unconstitutional

petitioner_arguments.text: Sections 3 and 4 and Control Order contravene fundamental right under Article 19(1)(f) and (g)
Section 3 and particularly section 4 ultra vires due to excessive delegation
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Delegation principles from Delhi Laws Act case

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 6 ultra vires makes section 3 inextricably connected and also ultra vires
Control Order contravenes sections 27, 28, 41 of Railways Act and void
Textile Commissioner given unregulated arbitrary discretion to grant/refuse permits similar to Dwarka Prasad case
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Dwarka Prasad v. State of UP; Section 4(3) UP Coal Control Order

respondent_arguments.text: Section 6 of the Act is constitutional

court_reasoning.text: Permit requirement is reasonable restriction in public interest under Article 19(5) for essential commodities during emergency; does not deprive right to dispose or transport but regulates it
court_reasoning.key_observation: Control necessary to prevent hampering supply; temporary Act

court_reasoning.text: Appellants never applied for permit so not aggrieved by discretion; Dwarka Prasad inapplicable as no unrestrained power here; policy to ensure even distribution and fair prices guides discretion
court_reasoning.key_observation: Forms and rules exist for permits; courts can check abuse

court_reasoning.text: Section 3 lays down policy of maintaining/increasing supplies, equitable distribution at fair prices; sufficient guidance; delegation valid per Delhi Laws and Privy Council cases
Section 4 authorizes delegation to specified classes; legislature selected instrumentalities; valid per Shannon case
Control Order supplements not conflicts with Railways Act; no implied repeal
court_reasoning.key_observation: Railways Act does not exclude disabilities

court_reasoning.text: Section 6 does not repeal but by-passes inconsistent laws; repeal if any by Parliament via s6 not delegate; no delegation issue
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court erred; s6 constitutional; sections not inextricably connected

holdings.text: Sections 3, 4 and 6 of Essential Supplies (Temporary Powers) Act 1946 constitutional
Cotton Textiles (Control of Movement) Order 1948 constitutional; does not violate Article 19(1)(f)(g)
Section 6 constitutional; does not affect validity of s3
Control Order does not contravene Railways Act

precedents_cited.case_name: Dwarka Prasad v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Unregulated discretion in licensing; inapplicable here as policy guides and appellants did not apply
Limits of delegation; essential policy must be laid down

precedents_cited.case_name: Shannon v. Lower Mainland Dairy Products Board
precedents_cited.relevance: Sub-delegation valid; Provincial Legislature supreme in sphere
Delegation to instrumentalities valid if policy laid down
Delegation to instrumentalities valid if policy laid down

statutes_cited.name: Essential Supplies (Temporary Powers) Act 1946
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers control orders for essential commodities; sections upheld as constitutional

statutes_cited.name: Cotton Textiles (Control of Movement) Order 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Regulates transport by permit; upheld as constitutional reasonable restriction

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Fundamental rights to trade and profession; reasonable restrictions permitted

statutes_cited.name: Indian Railways Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Control Order supplements, does not conflict

statutes_cited.name: Uttar Pradesh Coal Control Order
statutes_cited.relevance: Example of invalid unregulated discretion; distinguished

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appellants' contentions, upheld the constitutionality of sections 3, 4 and 6 of the Essential Supplies (Temporary Powers) Act 1946 and the Cotton Textiles (Control of Movement) Order 1948, reversed High Court's view on section 6, and allowed prosecution to proceed as directed by High Court.

key_quotes.text: The requirement of a permit in this regard cannot be regarded as an unreasonable restriction on the citizens right under sub-clauses (f) and (g) of article 19(1).
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Holds Control Order as valid reasonable restriction under Article 19(5)

key_quotes.text: Section 6 does not either expressly or by implication repeal any of the provisions of pre-existing laws neither does it abrogate them.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains effect of s6 as by-passing not repealing; upholds constitutionality

key_quotes.text: The policy underlying the Order is to regulate the transport of cotton textile in a manner that will ensure an even distribution of the commodity in the country and make it available at a fair price to all.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines guiding policy for delegation and discretion
